Award.AwardTitle: Management and Operation of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, 2008-2018, and Supporting Activities (Dugway)

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report represents projects that are funded by the United States Army Dugway Proving Ground and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).

This project supported the Four-Dimensional Weather (4DWX) System, a weather modeling and data processing system run by the Army for operational support of Department of Defense (DOD) weather testing. The project contributed to the  understanding of mesoscale and microscale meteorological phenomena in complex terrain (e.g., chinooks, gravity waves, drainage flow, cold-air damming, cascades of energy to the scales of large eddies and turbulence, sea breezes, wind storms, flash flooding, and severe thunderstorms), and how to predict those phenomena with greater skill using statistical and dynamical models.

NCAR conducted applied research and technology transfer to provide meteorologists with the software and expertise they needed to produce weather forecasts and analyses at the modeling scales, and with the accuracy and utility, required to support safe and cost-effective Department of Defense (DOD) testing at test locations across the country. Scientific advancements from these studies provided improvements to 4DWX and related technology, such as the Weather Research Forecasting Model (WRF). More general advancements in the field of numerical weather prediction were also made possible through the project.  Technology and expertise transferred to forecasters and other stakeholders at the ARMY ranges has enabled DOD to produce more efficient and accurate testing. Societal benefits include better weather forecasts at the ranges and throughout the United States, and has translated to greater safety and more effective use of national resources.

Project results were regularly communicated via collegial interaction, project-level meetings, training workshops, formal scientific presentations, journal articles, service on graduate committees, and contribution of code to community Numerical Weather Prediction models.

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2019
Modified by: Everette D Joseph
